Administer one ampule (150 mEq) of bicarbonate intravenously, then start maintenance intravenous fluids with sodium bicarbonate
Provide a bolus of normal saline, then initiate an insulin drip
Administer a subcutaneous dose of long-acting insulin, and offer the patient sugar-free fluids to drink
Provide a bolus of hypertonic saline, then administer a bolus of intravenous insulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable after volume repletion, insulin can be initiated. Insulin should be started as a drip, not as a bolus, because therapeutic insulin levels are rapidly achieved with the infusion alone, with less concern for rapid metabolic changes.

B) INCORRECT:

In most patients with DKA, IV fluids and insulin will correct the underlying acidosis. Bicarbonate therapy is not recommended unless the child has life-threatening hyperkalemia or very severe acidosis (pH <6.9) in the setting of compromised cardiac function. Treatment with bicarbonate may cause paradoxical acidosis of the central nervous system and, if rapidly corrected, hypokalemia.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is concerning for new-onset diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). DKA is defined as a blood glucose level ≥200 mg/dL with both acidemia (defined by venous pH <7.3 or a serum bicarbonate level <18 mEq/liter) and ketosis (ketonemia or ketonuria, defined as a beta-hydroxybutyrate level >3 mmol/liter or moderate or large urine ketones). The severity of DKA is determined by the degree of acidosis. See “Severity of DKA” table.

Patients presenting with DKA often report a preceding viral illness and may also report polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and/or unintentional weight loss. Other symptoms may include vague abdominal pain and vomiting, progressive lethargy, and abnormal deep breathing (Kussmaul respiration) with a fruity breath odor, although not all people can smell the ketones producing this scent. This patient’s respiratory rate is elevated for her age, suggesting respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis.

The first and most important step in DKA management involves prompt volume repletion with normal saline or an equivalent solution to correct the volume depletion induced by the osmotic diuresis from glycosuria. In this case, the patient has also lost volume due to vomiting. Intravenous (IV) fluid administration will correct the volume depletion and thus improve any related tachycardia or hypotension; it will also lower glucose levels and improve the acidosis through dilution and through improved perfusion of the kidneys and other organs.

Studies have shown the safety of using both 0.45% and 0.9% saline and a variety of approaches to replacing the calculated fluid deficit in this setting (over 36 to 48 hours), with no increased risk of cerebral edema. However, all studies use an initial fluid bolus of 10 mL/kg of IV fluids; it is not known whether more aggressive fluid-replacement regimens may induce rapid fluid shifts, which may precipitate cerebral edema. For patients in true hypovolemic shock, shock-protocol fluid resuscitation should be initiated.

Some patients with DKA may have hyperglycemia-induced pseudohyponatremia due to the dilutional effect of water movement into the serum as a result of glucose-induced hyperosmolarity. A corrected sodium level can be calculated to account for this, by adding 1.6 mEq to the measured serum sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in blood glucose above a level of 100 mg/dL. For example, the corrected serum sodium level for this patient, who presented with a serum sodium level of 134 mEq/liter and a blood glucose level of 510 mg/dL, would be as follows:
134 + (1.6 x 4.1) = 140.6 mEq/liter
As the hyperglycemia resolves, the measured serum sodium level is expected to increase; thus, the hyponatremia does not need to be treated separately.

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable after volume repletion, insulin can be initiated. Insulin should be started as a drip, not as a bolus, because therapeutic insulin levels are rapidly achieved with the infusion alone, with less concern for rapid metabolic changes. In mild, uncomplicated DKA, subcutaneous insulin protocols appear to be as safe and effective as IV insulin administration. These protocols use rapid-acting insulin, such as insulin lispro or insulin aspart. Long-acting basal insulin is not started until the patient is ready to transition off IV insulin. Patients are typically instructed to take nothing by mouth until the DKA has resolved.

Management of DKA also involves close monitoring of serum electrolyte levels — in particular, serum potassium. Patients with DKA may present with normal to elevated serum potassium levels, but they are, in fact, total-body potassium depleted. As the body attempts to correct the acidosis by shifting hydrogen cations into the cells, potassium shifts out of cells into the serum and is then lost in the urine. As the acidosis resolves with treatment of DKA, potassium shifts back into the cells, and the serum potassium level is subsequently reduced. To account for this, the IV fluids that are administered in the treatment of DKA are often supplemented with potassium once any initial hyperkalemia has resolved.

Given the level of monitoring and morbidity associated with DKA, most patients require hospital-level care for serial examination and testing.

Key learning point: A child presenting with altered mental status, vomiting, weight loss, and hyperglycemia in the setting of recent illness should be evaluated and treated for diabetic ketoacidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

In mild, uncomplicated DKA, subcutaneous insulin protocols appear to be as safe and effective as IV insulin administration, but these protocols use rapid-acting insulin, such as insulin lispro or insulin aspart. Long-acting basal insulin will not adequately treat DKA and is therefore not started until the patient is ready to transition off IV insulin. Patients are typically instructed to take nothing by mouth until the DKA has resolved; thus, this patient should not be offered anything to eat or drink at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic fluid, such as 3% sodium chloride, is not appropriate for volume repletion in patients with DKA. Some patients with DKA may have hyperglycemia-induced pseudohyponatremia due to the dilutional effect of water movement into the serum as a result of glucose-induced hyperosmolarity. As the hyperglycemia resolves, the measured serum sodium level is expected to increase; thus, the hyponatremia does not need to be treated separately. In addition, insulin should be started as a drip, not as a bolus, because therapeutic insulin levels are rapidly achieved with the infusion alone, with less concern for rapid metabolic changes.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes, diagnosed 2 years ago, presents to the emergency department (ED) with vomiting and diarrhea. Her younger brother has similar symptoms. She has been unable to tolerate any oral intake for the past 8 hours, and her blood glucose levels during this time have been in the range of 300 to 400 mg/dL (reference range, 60–100). She has not received any insulin since last night because of her poor oral intake.
On examination, she appears pale and has dry mucous membranes. Initial laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
436
60–100


Sodium (mEq/liter)
130
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.9
3.4–4.7


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
6
22–26


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.5
8.8–10.8


Urinalysis shows 4+ ketones and glucose.
The patient is treated with a normal saline bolus and then started on an intravenous insulin drip and maintenance intravenous fluids (normal saline with 20 mEq/liter of potassium chloride).
Which one of the following electrolyte abnormalities is most likely to occur during this patient’s treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The initial treatment for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) includes intravenous (IV) fluids and IV insulin in order to correct volume depletion and acidosis, but during the course of treatment, fluid and electrolyte shifts may result in electrolyte derangements.

Hypokalemia is the most common electrolyte abnormality that occurs during DKA treatment. At presentation, the serum potassium level may be normal, high, or low, but most patients with DKA have total-body potassium deficits due to transcellular shifts associated with osmotic diuresis, urinary losses, and losses from vomiting. A patient with gastroenteritis may have additional potassium losses related to emesis and diarrhea. Intracellular potassium is depleted by transcellular potassium shifts out of the cells. Insulin causes potassium influx into cells, resulting in low serum potassium levels after insulin is given. One study also demonstrated increased excretion of potassium in the urine after treatment with insulin, which may also contribute to hypokalemia.

Unless the patient is anuric or has a serum potassium level >4.5 mEq/liter, potassium supplementation should be started via IV fluids and continued throughout the course of IV insulin treatment. The initial recommended amount of potassium repletion in intravenous fluids is 40 mEq/liter. Hyperkalemia can occur if patients receive excessive potassium, but it is unlikely in this case, as the patient received only 20 mEq/liter of potassium in her fluids.

Key learning point: The most common electrolyte abnormality to occur after initiating an intravenous insulin infusion for treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis is hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperkalemia can occur if patients receive excessive potassium, but it is unlikely in this case, as the patient received only 20 mEq/liter of potassium in her fluids.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypocalcemia can occur as a result of excess phosphate repletion when potassium phosphate is used in intravenous fluids. This patient is receiving potassium chloride.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypercalcemia is not a complication of DKA treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia is not likely to occur during DKA treatment; in fact, mild hyponatremia may be evident at presentation of DKA because of the osmotic effects of hyperglycemia and may improve as hyperglycemia is corrected. The formula for calculating the corrected sodium level in the setting of hyperglycemia is: measured sodium + 1.6 [(plasma glucose − 100)/100] mg/dL. The corrected serum sodium level should rise during DKA treatment.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vomiting in the setting of polyuria and polydipsia, after having lost 10 kg of body weight in 4 weeks. He has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 100/62 mm Hg.
Initial laboratory testing yields the following results as well as large ketonuria:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
415
60–100


Venous pH
7.0
7.31–7.41


Sodium (mEq/liter)
130
135–147


Chloride (mEq/liter)
101
97–107


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
4
22–26


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.0
3.4–4.7


The patient is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), where he is given a 10-mL/kg bolus of normal saline. This is followed by a regular insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour and 0.9% sodium chloride with potassium chloride 40 mEq/liter at 1.5 times the maintenance rate, titrated based on close monitoring of the patient’s blood glucose and electrolyte levels. Six hours into treatment, the patient complains of acute headache, vomits, and has an episode of urinary incontinence.
During your subsequent assessment, the patient is sitting upright but is slow to answer questions and appears very tired. He is unable to state his name. His blood pressure is 155/110 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 78 beats per minute. His blood glucose level is now 199 mg/dL.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the rate of the insulin infusion to 0.15 units/kg/hour
Begin bag-mask hyperventilation to achieve a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 20 mm Hg
Obtain immediate CT of the brain

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Altered mental status in any child with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) should raise suspicion for cerebral edema and prompt further evaluation. Cerebral edema is the major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with DKA, accounting for up to 90% of deaths in these patients. Factors associated with increased risk for cerebral edema in DKA include younger age of diabetes onset, new onset of diabetes mellitus, and longer duration of symptoms. Cerebral edema typically occurs within 12 hours after the start of DKA treatment but can also be present before treatment starts.

Cerebral edema is considered to be present if a patient meets one of the following diagnostic criteria, two of the major criteria, or one major and one minor criterion.

Diagnostic criteria:

• Abnormal motor or verbal response to pain
• Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
• Cranial nerve palsy (especially in cranial nerves III, IV, and VI)
• Abnormal neurogenic respiratory pattern

Major criteria:

• Altered mentation or fluctuating level of consciousness
• Sustained heart-rate deceleration (decline by >20 beats per minute)
• Age-inappropriate incontinence

Minor criteria:

• Vomiting
• Headache
• Lethargy
• Diastolic blood pressure >90 mm Hg
• Age <5 years

When a diagnosis of cerebral edema is suspected, treatment with osmotic therapy should be initiated immediately, without confirmation from imaging studies. The preferred therapy is mannitol 0.5 to 1 g/kg administered intravenously over the course of 10 to 15 minutes. If there is no response to mannitol within 15 to 30 minutes, the dose may be repeated or hypertonic (3%) saline may be given at a dose of 2.5 to 5 mL/kg over 10 to 15 minutes. If necessary, hypertonic saline alone can be considered an alternative to mannitol for initial treatment, but there is concern about this approach: in one retrospective study, mortality rates were higher among patients treated with hypertonic saline alone than among those treated with mannitol. Mannitol therefore tends to be the first-line hyperosmolar agent used in this clinical setting.

During administration of the hyperosmolar agent, the head of the patient’s bed should be elevated to 30 degrees to promote cerebral venous drainage, with the head kept in midline position to limit compression of neck veins.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first step in treating cerebral edema associated with diabetic ketoacidosis is administration of mannitol.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood glucose level of 199 mg/dL is within the typical target range for DKA treatment (150–200 mg/dL) and does not explain his symptoms. Increasing the insulin infusion outside of the recommended ranges (0.05–0.1 unit/kg/hour) would place him at risk for hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertension is a compensatory response to increased intracranial pressure in an attempt to maintain cerebral perfusion. Administration of hydralazine could reduce cerebral perfusion pressure and would not address the underlying cause of increased intracranial pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient is currently protecting his airway and does not require ventilation assistance. In addition, hyperventilation with a partial pressure of carbon dioxide <22 mm Hg is associated with adverse outcomes.

E) INCORRECT:

When a diagnosis of cerebral edema is suspected, treatment with osmotic therapy should be initiated immediately, without confirmation from imaging studies.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with vomiting, lethargy, and mild abdominal pain. She has lost weight during the past several months. On examination, she has a temperature of 37.2°C (99°F), a pulse of 120/min, a respiratory rate of 24/min, and a blood pressure of 105/50 mm Hg. She is arousable to voice and complains of a headache. She has dry mucous membranes and mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding. A fingerstick glucose level obtained in triage is 520 mg/dL, and urinalysis is significant for high glucose and ketone levels. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


pH
7.1


Sodium
134 mEq/L


Potassium
4.7 mEq/L


Chloride
95 mEq/L


Bicarbonate
9 mEq/L


Blood urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


What is the most appropriate immediate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Provide a bolus of intravenous insulin, then start maintenance intravenous fluids
Administer bicarbonate intravenously, then start maintenance intravenous fluids with sodium bicarbonate
Provide a bolus of normal saline, then initiate an insulin drip
Administer a subcutaneous dose of long-acting insulin, and offer the patient sugar-free fluids to drink
Provide a bolus of hypertonic saline, then administer a bolus of intravenous insulin

In this case, the patient has also lost volume due to vomiting. Once the patient is hemodynamically stable after volume repletion, insulin can be initiated.

Key learning point: A child presenting with altered mental status, vomiting, weight loss, and hyperglycemia in the setting of recent illness should be evaluated and treated for diabetic ketoacidosis.

D) INCORRECT:
